photo.description: Angkor Wat (or Angkor Vat) is a temple complex at Angkor, Cambodia, built for the king Suryavarman II in the early 12th century as his state temple and capital city. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation—first Hindu, dedicated to the god Vishnu, then Buddhist. The temple is the epitome of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Check out my travelblog at <a href"http:www.175days.no" rel"nofollow">www.175days.no<a>

photo.title: Angkor Wat

photo.description: Angkor Wat is a temple complex at Angkor, Cambodia, built for the king Suryavarman II in the early 12th century as his state temple and capital city. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation – first Hindu, dedicated to the god Vishnu, then Buddhist. It is the world's largest religious building. The temple is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Angkor Wat combines two basic plans of Khmer temple architecture: the temple mountain and the later galleried temple, based on early South Indian Hindu architecture, with key features such as the Jagati. It is designed to represent Mount Meru, home of the devas in Hindu mythology: within a moat and an outer wall 3.6 kilometres (2.2 mi) long are three rectangular galleries, each raised above the next. At the centre of the temple stands a quincunx of towers. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Angkor Wat is oriented to the west; scholars are divided as to the significance of this. The temple is admired for the grandeur and harmony of the architecture, its extensive bas-reliefs, and for the numerous devatas (guardian spirits) adorning its walls. The modern name, Angkor Wat, means &quot;City Temple&quot;; Angkor is a vernacular form of the word &quot;nokor&quot; which comes from the Sanskrit word &quot;nagar&quot; meaning capital or city. Wat is the Khmer word for temple. Prior to this time the temple was known as Preah Pisnulok, after the posthumous title of its founder, Suryavarman II. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat<a>

It is the world's largest religious building. The temple is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Angkor Wat combines two basic plans of Khmer temple architecture: the temple mountain and the later galleried temple, based on early South Indian Hindu architecture, with key features such as the Jagati. It is designed to represent Mount Meru, home of the devas in Hindu mythology: within a moat and an outer wall 3.6 kilometres (2.2 mi) long are three rectangular galleries, each raised above the next. At the centre of the temple stands a quincunx of towers. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Angkor Wat is oriented to the west; scholars are divided as to the significance of this. The temple is admired for the grandeur and harmony of the architecture, its extensive bas-reliefs, and for the numerous devatas (guardian spirits) adorning its walls. The modern name, Angkor Wat, means &quot;City Temple&quot;; Angkor is a vernacular form of the word &quot;nokor&quot; which comes from the Sanskrit word &quot;nagar&quot; meaning capital or city. Wat is the Khmer word for temple. Prior to this time the temple was known as Preah Pisnulok, after the posthumous title of its founder, Suryavarman II. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat<a>

As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation – first Hindu, dedicated to the god Vishnu, then Buddhist. It is the world's largest religious building. The temple is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Angkor Wat combines two basic plans of Khmer temple architecture: the temple mountain and the later galleried temple, based on early South Indian Hindu architecture, with key features such as the Jagati. It is designed to represent Mount Meru, home of the devas in Hindu mythology: within a moat and an outer wall 3.6 kilometres (2.2 mi) long are three rectangular galleries, each raised above the next. At the centre of the temple stands a quincunx of towers. Unlike most Angkorian temples, Angkor Wat is oriented to the west; scholars are divided as to the significance of this. The temple is admired for the grandeur and harmony of the architecture, its extensive bas-reliefs, and for the numerous devatas (guardian spirits) adorning its walls. The modern name, Angkor Wat, means &quot;City Temple&quot;; Angkor is a vernacular form of the word &quot;nokor&quot; which comes from the Sanskrit word &quot;nagar&quot; meaning capital or city. Wat is the Khmer word for temple. Prior to this time the temple was known as Preah Pisnulok, after the posthumous title of its founder, Suryavarman II. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat<a>

photo.description: The Angkor Wat is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia,and appears on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Now if this isn't a beautiful sight, what is? This is a closer pre-sunrise shot of the central towers of the temple. Eagerly awaiting the rising sun now. It was a surreal sight. And for once, I was quite unmindful of the fidgety army of tourists and photographers all around me. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: Time to leave the Angkor Wat, but before I do, I simply must have myself photographed against the moat. It was pretty hot outside with the sun up high, and in my hurry, I made my usual error of not switching off the flash. With such bright back-lighting, the filler flash is crucial, but this is something I'm still learning by bitter experience. Note to self: wake up dammit! (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: Forward two steps, as I know the curiosity is killing you: this is a far shot of Angkor Wat as seen from the reflecting pool between the entrance complex and the main temple. The Angkor Wat is the largest Hindu (later Buddhist) temple complex in the world, situated at Angkor, in Siem Reap, Cambodia, built by King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century as his state temple and capital city. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation – first Hindu, dedicated to the god Vishnu, then Buddhist (after subsequent invasions). And yes, that's me in the foreground. Called the 'reflecting pool', the stagnant body of water in the foreground looks rather unimpressive by day, but gives an ethereal look and feel when you catch the sunrise at Angkor Wat. (pictures later in this set.) (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: This is the Angkor Wat entrance plaza, or ticket offices. You must possess an admission pass (an 'Angkor Pass') to visit the temples and sites in the Angkor Archaeological Park. Entry is not cheap, you have to buy passes for one day (not much use, you cannot see anything in one day, there are so many temples and so spread out), three days or one week. You have to call here on the first day, to pick up your ticket. On subsequent days, your tuk tuk will compulsorily enter the plaza, but will drive around the building. A group of people are stationed at the exit who will check your ticket. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.title: Angkor Wat entrance plaza

photo.description: Back on the entrance causeway, preparing for the nearly 1km trek in the hot afternoon sun to my tuktuk, I spot this scene, which turned out to be one of the more memorable scenes at the Angkor Wat temple. Here is a tourist delicately balancing her pink Canon camera on the stone causeway in an attempt to get a really low angle view of the Angkor Wat temple, the three spires of which are visible at the far end. The small compact camera was looking almost microscopic when viewed against those mighty structures. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: You are not allowed to take the direct path from the entrance corridor. That's that multi pillared structure you see stretching into the distance. You need to get down a few steps, get onto the grass and follow the 'Visit this Way' signs. It's frustating, especially when it is hot, muggy and sweaty, when you have to take a roundabout route or a detour, but what can one do? Although most of Cambodia, especially the heavily touristed areas, and more especially the Angkor Wat, is totally landmine free, the thought of unexploded landmines keeps you on your fixed track. (I know, I know, it's just my imagination!) (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: Steps at Angkor Wat in Cambodia. They are almost straight up and each step is very, very narrow. Visitors go up and then back down. You almost have to crawl up on your hands and knees and coming down is even much more difficult. I wasn't sure I was going to make it back down! This time my son went up and took the picture of me at the bottom.
photo.tags: stairs temple cambodia oldbuildings angkorwat siemreap steepstairs
photo.title: Angkor Wat in Siem Reap, Cambodia

photo.description: A final shot of Angkor Wat, the surrounding moat and greenery around it from the highest point. After hovering for a few minutes at the highest point till which the balloon will go, we are now preparing to descend, to return to terra firma. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.title: Angkor Wat aerial view

photo.description: As the sun rises higher, the crowd begins to thin. This is another silhouette shot of the Angkor Wat with the sun behind the temple. This is the reason one should avoid visiting the temple in the morning. As one of the few West facing Hindu temples, the light is always behind the structures in the mornings. The photographers with the heavy gear are all behind me now, (literally). Here a group of backpackers is getting pictures of each other with their simply point and shoot cameras and mobile phones. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
photo.tags: sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat tourists worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple backpackers angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom touristphotographers theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples
photo.title: Angkor Wat sunrise

photo.description: A large group of Japanese tourists had descended upon the reflecting lotus pool to catch the Angkor Wat sunrise. There were using anything from advanced dSLR cameras to mobile phones to capture the scene. The paraplegic lady in the wheel chair really caught my attention. She was using her mobile phone and was quite ecstatic when she got the scene. She kept smiling and laughing to herself looking at the scene on her phone's display. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
photo.tags: sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat tourists worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom touristphotographers theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples
photo.title: Angkor Wat sunrise

photo.description: The northern reflecting pool in front is the most popular sunrise location. To catch the sunrise, one needs arrive very early, well before sunrise. One can then see the sun rise behind the Angkor Wat, and providing a silhouette of Angkor’s distinctively shaped towers against a pink colored sunrise sky. Some of the best colors appear just before the sun breaks over the horizon. Timing apart, another important reason for an early arrival is the hordes of photographers out in force, some with tripod and very advanced equipment. It's difficult to get a good vantage point with all those crowds and heavy photo gear, many tripod mounted, all over the place. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
photo.tags: sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples
photo.title: Angkor Wat Sunrise

photo.description: A dried out tank in the Angkor Wat main shrine. It is customary for most South Indian shrines to have a tank on the premises, where the devouts must bathe, or (nowadays at least dip their feet) before they enter the temple. This is supposed to cleanse the body (or nowadays feet) before entering a place of prayer. This tank would have most probably served the same purpose. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
photo.tags: cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple templetank angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple
photo.title: Angkor Wat main shrine

photo.description: A massive Buddha statue inside the Angkor Wat temple. This is the only surviving statue from the original Khmer era. Most of the original statues were vandalized by invading troops, notably Vietnamese and Thai. In later years, many of the valuable statues were plundered by locals for the antiques market, becoming obscenely rich in the process, and ruining their own heritage in the process. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: The sun is now well and truly up. I returned later in the day to head towards the temple. It is not a good idea to visit the temple early in the morning as the sun is directly behind the building (the Angkor Wat is one of the few West facing Hindu temples) but a late morning or early afternoon visit should be OK. This is a daytime shot of the Angkor Wat reflected in the lotus reflecting pool. It looks so ordinary now! It was magic several hours earlier at sunrise! (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

photo.description: Architecturally, the elements characteristic of the style include : the ogival, redented towers shaped like lotus buds; half-galleries to broaden passageways; axial galleries connecting enclosures; and the cruciform terraces which appear along the main axis of the temple. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

photo.description: The stones, as smooth as polished marble, were laid without mortar with very tight joints that were sometimes hard to find. The blocks were held together by mortise and tenon joints in some cases, while in others they used dovetails and gravity. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Mannikka interprets these galleries as being dedicated to the king, Brahma, the moon, and Vishnu. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

photo.description: Every culture has its legends of the origin of the species. The Hindu creation myth &quot;Churning the Sea of Milk&quot; is shown in the bas-relief panel at the East gallery of Angkor Wat. In Hindu mythology, 13 precious things including the elixir of immortality were lost in the churning of the cosmic sea. Finding them again required a joint dredging operation between gods and demons. Assisting in this endeavor was the giant serpent Vasuki, who offered himself as a rope to enable twirling of a &quot;churning stick.&quot; The serpent was yanked back and forth in a giant tug-of-war that lasted for a thousand years. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

photo.description: Angkor Thommanon on a sad sad day. ~Angkor Wat World Heritage Site ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- <b>:))) Project Swami. :)))<b> Swami was my always cheery little traveling companion for the last 15 years. A pickpocket stole him from me while we were visiting Angkor Thommanon at Angkor Wat. It may sound absurd but it was heartbreaking. Now I am searching the world for just the right person, someone who can make another Swami. I hear there are people who are very adept at reconstructing legacy dolls etc. so I have compiled photos of him and have his dimensions for just that purpose. If you happen to know, or hear of such a person, I would be extremely grateful. Thank you in advance.
photo.tags: travel loss cambodia sad angkorwat temples angkor thommanon saddays vision:sky0741 vision:street0605 vision:outdoor0978
photo.title: Angkor Thommanon - where Swami disappeared on a sad sad day
